comments.commentBody: The NYT should do a story on the postal workers who take paid leave for imaginary injuries - both physical and psychological. It would make the these bus drivers look like kindergarteners in comparison.

So it's assault  only because it's in the contract. What is it if I spit in a Times reporter's eye? 51 bus drivers out of several thousand take off and these boards vomit hate and resentment. These are figures the MTA feeds to reporters. What else happened to these folks? Maybe there were threats as well and they didn't want to return to their regular route.
"The numbers are troubling" is as absurd as the numbers.
Just how do you spit in a bus driver's mouth anyway? There must be an instruction manual with diagrams for that maneuver.

My daughter's first food was an artichoke, since she needed something to rub her new teeth against.  This was shortly followed by avocado.  She loved them then, still loves them 18 years later, along with just about everything else.  (Okra, maybe not so much.)  We never understood the children's menu either.

I think this depends on the genetics of the parents. I'm an omnivore. My ex is a very picky eater. I was the one who primarily fed my son, and even as a very, very small baby, he outright rejected certain foods, again and again. He eats more variety now than many young children, but nowhere near where I was at his age, and new foods are a constant battle. We compromise, and he has to take one bite of everything on his plate, every time. And I make sure that every dinner has something involved that I know he will eat, so even if he hates the shrimp, or whatever, he can eat the green beans, or the carrots. In the end, I think he'll be a good eater, but not a great omnivore like his mama. He just isn't a genetically adventurous eater.
Unions are for the mentally weak.  Fits a Union Man to a tee.

The ONLY reason I look at the children's menu is because of prices.  It would be simply grand if restaurants offered half-portions of their normal offerings at half-prices.  At adult prices, who can afford to take kids, even if you do get a doggy bag out of it.
You can recover from a broken arm in less than three months!

One word UNIONS

The 21st Century death to a nation! Greece is just an example of what is to come! Government (public) union workers now outnumber private sector and earn 30-40% more in wages, most public unions has Cadillac Health Benefits (remember their exemption from taxes behind closed doors) then there are the pensions! Little wonder why our roads are in dis-repair and intra-structions failing! You can not be taxed enough to fix these union problems soon to surface here! Unions are the death of this nation! Google: california prison nurse overtime to get a taste of reality!

This must be a New York thing, because spitting is virtually unheard of in Chicago. Judging from the demeanor of some Chicago bus drivers after passengers have hurled insults, if there's someone who'll need a hospital, it'll be the offending passenger and not a driver.

Toughen up, New York transit workers, and stop creating fictitious incidents.
Put the drivers in a plexiglass cage so they can't perpetuate this ruse.
OMG when the NYT reports on stuff like this the end is, in fact, near.

If a driver is not traumatised by driving among other New York drivers, i find it hard to believe a driver could be traumatised by a spitter.  Three year olds in the playground cope with spitters, perhaps the drivers could take a lesson from them.

John Samuelsen's ridiculous and nonsensical comment notwithstanding, this is neither the fault of the union nor their employers, but rather the independent arbitrators who determine what constitutes legitimate grounds for taking "paid leave."  Who knows what else might qualify?  Having a bad dream?

So we lost 15-man years of driving which cost us

a) the 15 years of salary for 'recuperation'
b) the overtime (15 years x 1.5) to pay for the replacement driver

That's around 37.5 years. At about 100k/year (salary + benefits + pension), that's a 3.7 million dollar problem.)

So each of us donated 50c to the 'spit tax'

Not the biggest problem in the world, but if they find 5 or 10 like it, that's real money.
I can't decide if I'm thrilled to see this story, or depressed that what he describes needs to be explained.

Me too.  I just about can't stand to see my sister asking her son, at every restaurant, if he wants macaroni and cheese or chicken fingers, before even considering if there's anything on the "adult" menu that he might eat.  All I can do is wonder when, if ever, she will let him grow up.

Lesson learned: New Yorkers are tough*
*toughness does not include bus drivers.

Remember: LIRR is part of the MTA and that section had (and probably still has) major problems with disability "fraud." Three months for being spit on seems like a minor deal.

All kidding aside, nurses and doctors get stuck with used needles every day, yet many of them return to work a few hours later, after a quick trip to the ER for a work up.
Love this!  And get rid of baby food in jars and those awful kiddie snacks too!
I can't decide if I'm thrilled to see this story, or depressed that what he describes needs to be explained.

I'm sorry, but does driving a bus today compare even remotely to driving one in the 1970s (no a/c, no power steering, no automated hydraulics)?  On behalf of those of us who were there, I can only stand back aghast at what an impotent and unenviable lot New Yorkers have become, spitters and traumatized drivers alike.

@Rhonda,

Oh please, spitting is just as bad as physical battery? It is indicative of imminent attack? Oh, yes, definitely, a spit ball is so traumatizing that it definitely requires three months of paid leave. Give me a break. If that is what it takes to get a driver to lose it, then I fear for the safety of all the passengers under their watch. That is just a lame excuse to not work and get paid for it. It is not sustainable and will ultimately to lead to deficit and possible job loss. Oh wait, just deficit that will balloon, since after all, these are union protectionist jobs.

I have no sympathy for these bus drivers. You do not need MONTHS to recover from being spat upon, that is just taking advantage of the system and these drivers should be ashamed of themselves.

Well said. Parents would do well to realize that our job is not to give our children what they think they want, but to teach them skills, to give them opportunities and to guide them in developing their character....we are surrounded by a generation that never experienced family dinners at Grandma's (w/or w/out the card table) but rather Happy Meals in the mini van on the way to soccer practice.  Kudos to the man, the parent, the chef.  I know where we'll be dining on our next trip to the city.
